ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 12--More students need to take courses on Justice, therefore more should be offered! There are justice implications in every decision made in any field so it is crucial for people to be aware of EJ in their own work!1,2,3--the readings were perfect and really helped show many components of EJ. the reading responses were great to have us do so we could reflect on the readings and get more out of them and make connections. And the student presentations were an excellent additions. Everything felt very equal--not a professor giving us lectures but rather everyone was able and comfortable to talk about what their thoughts and interpretations. Great class!!!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I thought our class formed a great discussion group, which was facilitated well by Prof. Doolittle. We were able to be honest about the challenges and contradictions of understanding and acting on issues of environmental justice. Furthermore, we were able to develop our knowledge into a disseminate-able form through the class website that was our collective final project.

It was a rigorous exploration of topics I had come across but not delved into. It was also focused on communicating the questions, principles, and solutions to a non-justice-focused audience, which I think is really important.
The lively discussions and response papers stimulate students to get deeper into the subjects.

Perspectives on Environmental Injustices helped me learn so much about environmental justice movements and issues nationally and internationally. The theory was very rich and to me revelatory. Yet we also read about research and learned about many lived experiences that illustrated the concepts we worked on. This is an incredibly important and well-rounded class. Class discussions were all at a high level and provided an environment that was challenging and safe for participants.

How equal it was--not just a professor giving lecturesI really appreciated how everyone had done the readings and then contributed to discussion. It was never forced or lacking in conversation. We had great dialogue!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It would have been great to have interacted with more EJ activists, and to have had field trips to interact with actual EJ groups. This might be overloading the course (and be too much for it to do), but it would also be great to be able to do some skills training around how to incorporate justice concerns into environmental impact assessments, or to learn more concrete methods about community-based participatory research.
This course was all-around excellent! This year was the first that students created a website as a final project, so I predict that in the future that project will be even more smooth.
None--other than how to get more people interested.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course has provided a scholarly grounding in justice theory and the research behind the environmental justice movement, which I find very valuable as a framing for past and future social justice/EJ work.
I am really focused on environmental justice issues internationally, so it gave me a space to explore those more rigorously, as well as to learn more about the domestic EJ considerations.

I think this course is essential for me as a student who plans on working in an environmental field. For me it serves as a way to learn about how environmentalism plays out in people's lives; it describes many key issues and also little-discussed struggles of populations who are not always given enough time in discussions.
EJ is relevant to absolutely every field of study and area of work! More people without previous work and interest in the topic need to take the course, especially!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Really central to my academic interests.
Out of my curiosity and lack of understanding on the history of environmentalism in the US.
I have a deep interest in the topic and I think it is crucial to understand and consider for any path my future may take

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
It exceeded my expectations. I really loved it.
Yes
Absolutely. It introduced me to entirely new paradigms. In the future I will often use the framework I gained from the class.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to work with other students and discuss the class issues with them. The other students in the class were really great.
I really enjoyed working on the website and felt that it was a great way to bridge the course material to the real world.
Poorly organized, vast differences in level of motivation.

It was very rewarding to work as part of a group. It definitely enhanced my own intellectual progress, and I think working together enabled us to accomplish projects we could not have done on our own.

Communication is always challenging, especially when trying to figure out a vision for the project but things came together and we divided up responsibilities which allowed for a bit more freedom to pursue our own visions

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it! This adds a valuable dimension to any kind of environmental and international development discussion/work - really, I think it should be required of anyone interested in "environmental management".
I think this is a course that all FES students should have to take. It offers a perspective on the environmental movement that you do not get in other courses.
You aren't going to find much diversity of opinion, but you will learn.
One hundred percent take this class! Approach it with a commitment to challenging your established perspective, and dive into the material so that you get a lot out of it.
take it and love it! You cannot fake your way through this class if you don't read, so you must read!!
